title: Corporation Tax Rates 2024: Complete UK Guide
description: Everything you need to know about UK corporation tax rates for 2024/25, including small profits rate, marginal relief calculations, and tax planning strategies.
author: TaxBlog UK
content:
UK Corporation Tax Rates for 2024/25

Understanding corporation tax rates is crucial for effective business planning. Since April 2023, the UK has operated a two-tier corporation tax system with different rates depending on your company's profits.

Current Corporation Tax Rates

  • Small profits rate: 19% - For companies with profits up to £50,000
  • Main rate: 25% - For companies with profits over £250,000
  • Marginal rate: 26.5% - Effective rate on profits between £50,000 and £250,000

These rates apply to accounting periods beginning on or after 1 April 2023.

Understanding the Small Profits Rate

The small profits rate of 19% applies to companies with taxable profits not exceeding £50,000. This rate helps smaller businesses maintain more working capital for growth and investment.

Key Points:

  • Applies automatically - no election needed
  • Based on total taxable profits, not turnover
  • Includes all income subject to corporation tax
  • Pro-rated for accounting periods shorter than 12 months

Marginal Relief: The Middle Ground

Companies with profits between £50,000 and £250,000 benefit from marginal relief, which creates a gradual transition between the small profits rate and main rate.

How Marginal Relief Works

The marginal relief calculation ensures a smooth progression of tax rates:

  1. Calculate tax at the main rate (25%)
  2. Apply the marginal relief fraction: 3/200
  3. Relief = (Upper limit - Profits) × 3/200
  4. Tax due = Main rate tax - Marginal relief

Example Calculation

For a company with £150,000 profits:

  • Tax at main rate: £150,000 × 25% = £37,500
  • Marginal relief: (£250,000 - £150,000) × 3/200 = £1,500
  • Tax due: £37,500 - £1,500 = £36,000
  • Effective rate: 24%

Associated Companies Rules

The profit thresholds are divided by the number of associated companies plus one. This prevents tax avoidance through company splitting.

What Makes Companies Associated?

  • One company controls another
  • Both under common control
  • Control generally means >50% ownership
  • Includes worldwide companies

Impact on Thresholds

With associated companies, the thresholds become:

  • Lower limit: £50,000 ÷ (number of associates + 1)
  • Upper limit: £250,000 ÷ (number of associates + 1)

Special Rates and Reliefs

Patent Box Rate: 10%

Companies can elect for a 10% rate on profits from patented inventions and certain other intellectual property.

R&D Tax Credits

  • SME scheme: 186% deduction (effectively 21.5% credit)
  • RDEC scheme: 20% credit for large companies
  • Enhanced support for R&D intensive companies

Creative Industries Reliefs

Special reliefs available for:

  • Film production
  • Animation and children's TV
  • Video games development
  • Theatre productions

Planning for Corporation Tax

Key Strategies

  1. Timing of Expenses
    • Accelerate deductible expenses before rate increases
    • Consider capital allowances timing
  2. Dividend vs Salary Planning
    • Balance corporation tax and personal tax efficiency
    • Consider pension contributions
  3. Group Structure Review
    • Assess impact of associated companies rules
    • Consider group relief opportunities
  4. Investment Planning
    • Maximize capital allowances
    • Consider Annual Investment Allowance (£1 million)

Key Dates and Deadlines

  • Payment deadline: 9 months and 1 day after accounting period end
  • Filing deadline: 12 months after accounting period end
  • Quarterly instalments: Required for large companies (profits >£1.5m)

Recent Changes and Future Outlook

The reintroduction of the small profits rate in April 2023 marked a significant change from the previous flat 19% rate. This tiered system aims to:

  • Support smaller businesses with lower rates
  • Generate additional revenue from larger corporations
  • Maintain UK competitiveness internationally

Future considerations include potential adjustments to thresholds and ongoing discussions about digital services taxation.

faqs.question: When do I pay corporation tax at 25% instead of 19%?
faqs.answer: You pay the main rate of 25% when your company's taxable profits exceed £250,000. If profits are between £50,000 and £250,000, you'll pay an effective rate between 19% and 25% due to marginal relief. Companies with profits up to £50,000 pay only 19%.

faqs.question: How do associated companies affect my corporation tax rate?
faqs.answer: Associated companies share the rate thresholds. For example, if you have one associated company, the £50,000 and £250,000 limits are halved to £25,000 and £125,000. This prevents artificial splitting of businesses to benefit from lower rates.

faqs.question: What is marginal relief and how is it calculated?
faqs.answer: Marginal relief smooths the transition between the 19% and 25% rates for profits between £50,000 and £250,000. It's calculated as (Upper limit - Taxable profits) × 3/200. This creates an effective marginal rate of 26.5% on profits in this band.

faqs.question: Can I still claim R&D tax credits with the new rates?
faqs.answer: Yes, R&D tax credits remain available. The SME scheme offers 186% deduction, while large companies use the RDEC scheme with a 20% credit. From April 2024, there are enhanced rates for R&D intensive companies spending over 30% on R&D.

faqs.question: Do the new rates apply to all companies?
faqs.answer: The rates apply to most UK companies, but there are exceptions. Companies in the Patent Box regime pay 10% on relevant profits, and some oil and gas companies pay higher rates. Investment companies may have different rules for certain income types.

faqs.question: How do I know if companies are 'associated' for tax purposes?
faqs.answer: Companies are associated if one controls another (usually >50% ownership) or both are under common control. This includes overseas companies and dormant companies (with exceptions). The test applies at the end of the previous accounting period.

faqs.question: What happens if my accounting period straddles the rate change?
faqs.answer: If your accounting period spans 1 April 2023, profits are time-apportioned. The portion before April 2023 is taxed at 19%, while the portion after is subject to the new tiered rates. HMRC provides guidance on precise calculations.

faqs.question: Is dividend tax affected by the corporation tax changes?
faqs.answer: Corporation tax changes don't directly affect dividend tax rates, but they impact the profits available for distribution. Higher corporation tax means less post-tax profit for dividends, affecting overall tax efficiency for owner-managed businesses.
